Goldfinches are gathering in flocks to feed on thistle seeds. William Cobbett in his Rural Rides (1830) described how in September 1826 he was going along a road in Wiltshire that had masses of thistles beside it. Flocks of goldfinches were feeding on them, and rose up and flew ahead of him, with others continually joining them as he went on, until he estimated that there was “a flock of 10,000 flying before me”. That sounds exceptional, but large flocks of goldfinches still gather in such places. They eat the seeds that are still on the thistle tops, and also those that have fallen to the ground beneath. When they are disturbed the air around fills with the flashing gold of their wing bars, and they may settle, with tinkling twitterings, in nearby trees. Some of the young birds among them still have grey heads, but many have already acquired the wonderful red, white and black heads of their parents.

The musicians displayed exemplary speed control on Maxwell Davies’s String Quintet of 2014, which justifiably crowned the night
September 22 2017, 12:01am, The Times
★★★★☆In the new Wigmore Hall season, the Nash Ensemble will be largely spending their time spraying audiences with French perfume: Ravel, Debussy, Poulenc and their ilk. However, we had none of that on Wednesday. The smells and sounds were predominantly new and British. We had Orkney reels and luminous skies from Maxwell Davies, Yorkshire mists from John Casken, and the spiky crags of Birtwistle-land. All these proved well worth savouring, especially with the Nash musicians, succulently vigorous and precise, as guides.

Without accompanying visuals, this celebration of the music in Jim Jarmusch’s films wasn’t much more than a random bunch of songs
September 22 2017, 12:01am, The Times
★★☆☆☆There was a fundamental design flaw in this celebration of the music in Jim Jarmusch’s films: no films. There was black-and-white footage of buildings at the beginning, but nothing from Down by Law, Mystery Train or any of the American director’s other stylish, unhurried classics.
Music is a huge component of Jarmusch’s movies. To remove the films from the music and not contextualise it in any other way was to leave the concert without narrative thrust, resulting in a random bunch of songs that, unless you were a Jarmusch nut, did not have any real cohesion.

★★★★☆The tentacles of the musical octopus celebrating Simon Rattle’s arrival at the London Symphony Orchestra spread far and wide. Though the script fails to fully engage, its star keeps it in the air
September 22 2017, 12:01am, The Times
★★★☆☆She is on stage when we arrive, sitting in an armchair. Emily Stilson was an aviatrix and wing walker but now she is in her seventies, an old woman enjoying her own company. But what’s this? Lights flash. Blackout! Now it gets very noisy. Suddenly Emily is airborne, circling, tumbling above us, lit up in the dark centre swathe of this traverse staging. She is saying words, words, words, but it is all, to use the technical term, gobbledegook.
